chapter.fullItemName: Assessing for underlying causes and contributing factors
chapter.htmlHeader: Identifying underlying causes and contributing factors
chapter.htmlStringContent:
• Consider and look for the presence of any causes or conditions that may exacerbate urinary incontinence or overactive bladder.
    • Ask about fluid intake and the amount and type of fluids, for example, caffeine and alcohol.
    • Identify symptoms indicating an increased likelihood of a more serious diagnosis, for example, haematuria, persisting bladder or urethral pain, recurrent urinary tract infection, constant leakage (suggests a fistula). 
    • Ask about any drugs the woman is taking that could be causing or exacerbating the incontinence.
      • Drugs that may be associated with urinary incontinence include alpha-1 adrenoceptor antagonists, antipsychotics, anticholinergics, anti-parkinsonism drugs, antidepressants, benzodiazepines, beta-adrenoceptor antagonists, diuretics, and hormone replacement therapy.
    • Ask about previous history of investigations and treatment, urinary tract disorders, low spinal surgery, prolapse or hysterectomy, and obstetric and gynaecological history.
    • Consider and look for neurological conditions, for example, multiple sclerosis, spinal cord injury, Parkinson's disease. 
    • Consider and look for systemic disease, such as heart failure and diabetes mellitus. 
    • Consider and look for cognitive impairment. 
  • Perform urine dipstick analysis in all women presenting with urinary incontinence to test for blood, glucose, protein, leucocytes, and nitrites.
    • If the woman has symptoms of a urinary tract infection (UTI) and dipstick analysis is positive for both leukocytes and nitrites, send a mid-stream urine (MSU) sample for culture and sensitivities and prescribe an antibiotic whilst waiting for the culture result.
      • For more information, see the CKS topic on Urinary tract infection (lower) - women.

Assessing for underlying causes and contributing factors
Assessing the severity of urinary incontinence

subChapters.htmlHeader: Basis for recommendation
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
Causes and conditions that may exacerbate urinary incontinence

  • The recommendation to look for causes and conditions that may exacerbate urinary incontinence are based on the National Institute for Health and Care Excellence (NICE) guidelines Urinary incontinence and pelvic organ prolapse in women: management  [NICE, 2019] and Urinary incontinence in women: the management of urinary incontinence in women [National Collaborating Centre for Women's and Children's Health, 2013], and expert opinion from European guidelines on Urinary incontinence  [EAU, 2018]. 
  • The potential causes to exclude are based on information in these sources, Australian and New Zealand guidelines on non-neurogenic overactive bladder [Tse et al, 2016], and review articles [Barkin et al, 2017; Itam and Singh, 2017; Lukacz et al, 2017; BMJ Best Practice, 2018]. 
    • Evidence demonstrating a cause-effect relationship between drug usage and incontinence is sparse [Tsakiris et al, 2008] and there is little evidence to suggest that changing non-incontinence medication can improve urinary incontinence symptoms (and it may be harmful) [EAU, 2018]. 
    • Previous surgery for urinary incontinence or pelvic organ prolapse may interfere with the normal support mechanisms of the vagina and urethra [National Collaborating Centre for Women's and Children's Health, 2013].

Exclude urinary tract infection

  • The recommendation to perform urinary dipstick analysis in all women presenting with urinary incontinence is based on the NICE guideline Urinary incontinence and pelvic organ prolapse in women: management [NICE, 2019] and is consistent with European guidelines [EAU, 2018]. 
    • Detection of haematuria, pyuria, and glycosuria can suggest a co-existing condition that is associated with incontinence and requires further assessment [Itam and Singh, 2017; Lukacz et al, 2017; EAU, 2018]. 
    • Urinary tract infection may cause incontinence or worsening of existing symptoms [EAU, 2018].
